instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-00165 Wont boot up - PPBUS_G3H 1.
threads.message:
This board came in for no boot, looked over the entire board, and no signs of liquid or burned caps, super clean, paying close attention I noticed C7372(PPBUS _S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS & ground) was burned, took it off and replaced it, still did not boot up, any ideas?

Board has also been ultrasonic cleaned after removed burned capacitor, 

D7005

PIN 1 - 1.09V PPBUS_G3H
PIN 2 - 16.5V PP18V5 DCIN ISOL R
PIN 3 - 16.2V PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H

threads.title: 820-00165 Wont boot up - PPBUS_G3H 1.
threads.message: Probably also killed the ppbus fuse (F7040? schematic not in front of me). Check both sides.

threads.title: 820-00165 Wont boot up - PPBUS_G3H 1.
threads.message:
Yeah, brain fart again lol Thank you!! 

I was thinking too much on this one,

threads.title: 820-00165 Wont boot up - PPBUS_G3H 1.
threads.message:
ok, so I went ahead and replaced PPBUS fuse, without [LEFT][COLOR=#353535][FONT=Arial][SIZE=12px]C7372(PPBUS _S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS) being put on, put a new capacitor on, and it burned it again :/

not sure whats going on there, any ideas?[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR][/LEFT]

threads.title: 820-00165 Wont boot up - PPBUS_G3H 1.
threads.message: You likely still have a short circuit. What is the resistance to ground on PPBUS_G3H now?

threads.title: 820-00165 Wont boot up - PPBUS_G3H 1.
threads.message:
I ended up leaving the capacitor off, since it there are many in the line, must have been a short somewhere,

thank you guys!!

threads.title: 820-00165 Wont boot up - PPBUS_G3H 1.
threads.message: I still think you should put effort into finding a suitable replacement cap, but I suppose this can be considered solved now.
